creditline: Gift of the Vesterheim Norwegian-American Museum
inscription: in pencil inside cover: 93.70.1 | in pencil inside cover: to Tita and Ernest / for their / 12 year anniversary / Mars 17th / 1963 / from / (illegible) & Forl(illegible)
markings: sticker inside cover: [Reeves' Sketch Book manufacturer's sticker] | stamp in purple above sticker: Christ. Engebretsen & Søn / Kunstmalerartikler
medium: Bound book with pencil, pastel, and ink sketches
text:
Jørleif Uthaug used this sketchbook during July of 1952 in the vicinity of Vågakallen, a 3094-foot-tall mountain on the island of Austvågøya in Norway's Lofoten archipelago, more than 68 degrees north. The first view, taken from the town of Kabelvåg, shows the mountain in the background and a fishery. Cod has been sought from this port since the twelfth century. In Uthaug’s hands the mountain takes on many guises as we page through the book: crystalline gem, brooding hulk, riot of summertime greens, distant sentinel, whorl of veils, enameled vase, yellow lacework, and so forth. Fishing shacks, docks, and sturdy boats dot the shores and waters below Vågakallen’s looming presence.

At first, Uthaug’s tendency to simplify and abstract may lead one to think that the drawings are childish, but they are more in the Picasso-Klee tradition of drawings that are child-like, immediate, direct, unassuming.
title: Sketchbook of Norwegian coastal scenes
